# Notes
Hi Dr. Erwig,

  

I have what ended up being a big email. Let me know if you would rather go over it in a meeting than read it.

  

List Transformers

Before I start, it has become clear that I tend to use a lot of ellipses now, so I'm very used to the notation. If any of this is confusing or cold be clarified, please let me know.

  

![](data:image/png;base64,)

fig. 1*

![](data:image/png;base64,)

fig. 2* **

  

x1 .. xN are all ellipsis-matched lists. For fig. 2, they have to be non-empty.

  

f :: a1 -> ... -> aN -> b

  

Fig. 1 can be translated as:

zipWithN f (range (x_1, i_1, j_1)) ... (range (x_N, i_N, j_N))

  

Fig. 2 can be translated as:

foldr1 (⊙) $ zipWithN f (range (x_1, i_1, j_1)) ... (range (x_N, i_N, j_N))

  

Where

  

zipWithN is the appropriate zip given the number of branches.

  

range :: ([a], Int, Int) -> [a]

range (xs, i, j) | i < 0        = []

                 | i <= j       = drop (i-1) $ take j $ xs

                 | otherwise    = let

                    i' = length xs - i + 1

                    j' = length xs - j + 1

                  in drop (i'-1) $ take j' $ reverse xs

  

So we could say that ellipsis without element skipping are syntactic sugar for (foldr1 or id),  zipWithN, take, drop (reverse or id).  Maybe a Haskell super-folder can do it all in a foldr, I'm not sure.

  
* Note that I did not show the pattern matching expression in fig. 1 and fig. 2 – this is on purpose, because x1 through xN do not have to be different lists, although they could be. For example, 

pairAdj (x[1] ... x[n]) = pair(x[1], x[2]) ... pair(x[n-1], x[n])

or

zip (x[1] ... x[n]) (y[1] ... y[m]) = pair(x[1], y[1]) ... pair(x[n], y[m])

Are both representable. 

  

** is ⊙ appropriate for "any infix operator"?

  

Element Skipping

I imagine element skipping could be done like this:

everyOther (x[1] ... x[n]) = (x[1] x[3] ... x[<=n]).

  

That way, we don't have to guess about n. (if n was even, x[1] x[3] ... x[10] does not make sense). This was inspired by Rust's (1..=10). 

  

The following expression:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

  

Can be translated as:

zipWithN f (rangeSkip (x_1, i_1, j_1, k_1)) ... (rangeSkip (x_N, i_N, j_N, k_N)),

  

where

  

rangeSkip :: ([a], Int, Int, Int) -> [a]

rangeSkip (xs, ifst, isnd, ilst) =

    let xs' = range (xs, ifst, ilst)

        skipN = abs (isnd - ifst)

    in map snd $ filter (\(i, _) -> i `mod` skipN == 0) $ enumerate xs'

  

Note that, in cases where i > k, you would have to change the inequality to >=k.

  

Arbitrary Skipping

I have been trying to think of some way to do arbitrary skipping. This would not work:

  

x[g(i)] ... x[g(k)]

  

Because that could just mean that the first element is `g(i)`​ and the last element is `g(k)`​.

  

Maybe something like this:

  

x[>=i] ..g.. x[<=k]

-- or

x[g] ... x[g] | >=i..<=k

-- or

x[>=i] ... x[<=k] | g

  

Where g would be a function:

g :: Int -> Int

That takes a sequence of integers (map g [0..]) and outputs indices, which is dropped until it reaches "i", and then taken until it reaches above "k". 

  

I have created an ellip2SkipArb transformer, but it feels a lot more confusing and unclear than the ellip2Skip function. In `transformer.hs`​, you can run it with, for example:

ellip2SkipArb (\x _->x) (xs, 1, n) (xs, 1, n) (\i -> i*2)

  

This would skip every other element. The last argument is the skip function.

  

This is still something I'm thinking about, and my work might have flaws. There are still unanswered questions: Would g=(`div` 2) mean every element would be repeated? Or would it just be a slower way to write the list? Would g=1 repeat forever? You could do g=(2 * i `div` 3) to repeat every other element:

  

case [1..5] of

    x[1] ... x[n] => (x[>=1] ... x[<=n] | \i -> (2 * i `div` 3))

  

== [1 1 2 3 3 4 5 5]

  

But the notation is confusing, and the only use I can think of is generating THAC0 tables in Advanced Dungeons & Dragons.

  

Examples

Here are some of my examples, some on nested Ellipsis. please let me know if you have any more ideas. 

  

rotL (x[1] ... x[n]) = let k' = k % n

      in (x[k'+1] ... x[n]) ++ (x[1] ... x[k'])

  

pairAdj (x[1] ... x[n]) =

      (x[1], x[2]) ... (x[n-1], x[n])

  

zip (x[1] ... x[n]) (y[1] ... y[m]) = 

      (x[1], y[1]) ... (x[n], y[m])

  

inits (x[1] ... x[n]) =

      (x[1] ... x[1]) ... (x[1] ... x[n])

  

subLists (x[1] ... x[n]) = 

      ((x[1] ... x[1]) ... (x[1] ... x[n])) ++ subLists (x[2] ... x[n])

  

combinations (x[1] ... x[n]) (y[1] ... y[m]) =

      ((x[1], y[1]) ... (x[1], y[m])) ... ((x[n], y[1]) ... (x[n], y[m]))

  

I have also been working on groupBy, which might be done recursively, but does not have any simple implementation that I can think of.

  

I have not done a lot of work on it, but nested ellipsis in patterns could make good matrix transformers:

  

transpose :: [[a]] -> [[a]]

transpose ((x[1][1] ... x[1][m]) ... (x[n][1] ... x[n][m] =

    ((x[1][1] ... x[n][1]) ... (x[1][m] ... x[n][m]))

  

It is a lot of 1s and ms and ns to keep track of, though. Sometimes line breaks can be helpful:

Oops, I pressed ctrl+enter, serves me right for editing a giant email. Sorry if there are any typos or unreviewed parts. I was just about to finish with this:

transpose xs = case xs of

    ((x[1][1] ... x[1][m]) ...

     (x[n][1] ... x[n][m])) =>

  

    ((x[1][1] ... x[n][1]) ...

     (x[1][m] ... x[n][m]))

  

Transformer.hs is attached.

  

Thank you,

Liam

# Archive
Hi Dr. Erwig,

  

List Transformers

Before I start, it has become clear that I tend to use a lot of ellipses now, so I'm very used to the notation. If any of this is confusing or cold be clarified, please let me know.

  

![](data:image/png;base64,)

fig. 1*

![](data:image/png;base64,)

fig. 2* **

  

x1 .. xN are all ellipsis-matched lists. 

  

f :: a1 -> ... -> aN -> b

  

Fig. 1 can be translated as:

zipWithN f (range (x_1, i_1, j_1)) ... (range (x_N, i_N, j_N))

  

Fig. 2 can be translated as:

foldr1 (⊙) $ zipWithN f (range (x_1, i_1, j_1)) ... (range (x_N, i_N, j_N))

  

Where

  

zipWithN is the appropriate zip given the number of branches.

  

range :: ([a], Int, Int) -> [a]

range (xs, i, j) | i <= j       = drop (i-1) $ take j $ xs

                 | otherwise    = let

                    i' = length xs - i + 1

                    j' = length xs - j + 1

                  in drop (i'-1) $ take j' $ reverse xs

  
* Note that I did not show the pattern matching expression in fig. 1 and fig. 2 – this is on purpose, because x1 through xN do not have to be different lists, although they could be. For example, 

pairAdj (x[1] ... x[n]) = pair(x[1], x[2]) ... pair(x[n-1], x[n])

or

zip (x[1] ... x[n]) (y[1] ... y[m]) = pair(x[1], y[1]) ... pair(x[n], y[m])

Are both representable. 

  

** is ⊙ appropriate for "any infix operator"?

  

Element Skipping

I imagine element skipping could be done like this:

everyOther (x[1] ... x[n]) = (x[1] x[3] ... x[<=n]).

  

That way, we don't have to guess about n. (if n was even, x[1] x[3] ... x[10] does not make sense). This was inspired by Rust's (1..=10). 

  

The following expression:

![](data:image/png;base64,)

  

Can be translated as:

zipWithN f (rangeSkip (x_1, i_1, j_1, k_1)) ... (rangeSkip (x_N, i_N, j_N, k_N)),

  

where

  

rangeSkip :: ([a], Int, Int, Int) -> [a]

rangeSkip (xs, ifst, isnd, ilst) =

    let xs' = range (xs, ifst, ilst)

        skipN = abs (isnd - ifst)

    in map snd $ filter (\(i, _) -> i `mod` skipN == 0) $ enumerate xs'

  

Note that, in cases where i > k, you would have to change the inequality to >=k.

  

I have been trying to think of some way to do arbitrary skipping. Maybe something like this:

  

x[i] ..g(i).. x[<=k]

  

where `i`​ would be reserved, and g(i) would be a function:

g :: Int -> Int

I have created an ellip2SkipArb transformer, but it feels a lot more confusing and unclear than the ellip2Skip function. In transformer.hs, you can run it with, for example:

ellip2SkipArb (\x _->x) (xs, 1, n) (xs, 1, n) (\i -> i*2)

This would skip every other element. 

  

Examples

Here are some of the
